alert.note: Alert for North Central; San Juan and Vicinity (Puerto Rico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS San Juan (San Juan, Puerto Rico)
info.headline: Rip Current Statement issued January 11 at 10:45AM AST until January 13 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan
info.description: ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE FRIDAY NIGHT... ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 6 PM THIS EVENING TO 6 AM AST FRIDAY... * WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents due to breaking waves around 6 to 7 feet becoming 8 to 10 feet tonight. * WHERE...North-facing beaches of central Puerto Rico and the Greater San Juan Metropolitan area. * WHEN...For the high rip current risk, through late Friday night For the high surf advisory, tonight. * IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety. High surf can wash over rocks and jetties putting people and pets in danger.
info.instruction: There is a high risk of rip currents. Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and signs. If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly. A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and dangerous swimming conditions.

area.areaDesc: North Central; San Juan and Vicinity
